statement.p: Rewrite the expression simplified and using only positive exponents.

solution.p: We use the properties of exponents to help us here, remembering that \displaystyle{\frac{a^m}{a^n} = a^{m-n}} and \left(a^m\right)^{n}=a^{mn}
You might need to go back to previous units to review how to add fractions.
To add two fractions with different denominators, we first have to find a common denominator.
In this case, the least common multiple of 9 and 45 is 45.
Look at the first fraction \displaystyle{-\frac{1}{9}}. To change the denominator to 45, we multiply 5 at both the top and bottom, and we have:
The second fraction already has the common denominator.
Finally, we can do the addition. The full process is:

statement.p: Subtract one fraction from the other: \displaystyle{-\frac{2}{7}-\frac{4}{35}}

solution.p: To add or subtract two fractions with different denominators, we first have to find the common denominator.
In this case, the least common multiple of 7 and 35 is 35.
Look at the first fraction \displaystyle{-\frac{2}{7}}. To change the denominator to 35, we multiply 5 at both the top and bottom, and we have:
Since the second fractions denominator is the same as the common denominator, there is no need to make changes to the second fraction.
Finally, we add or subtract the numerators and keep the common denominator unchanged. The whole process is:
We must follow the order of operations when simplifying this expression. Begin by doing the division.
According to the order of operations, the multiplication has higher priority than the addition.
You might need to go back to previous units to review how to add fractions.
You might need to go back to previous units to review how to add fractions.

p.p: We will factor t^{2}-11t+30 where a=1, b=-11, and c=30.
Mental Method: When we factor a polynomial in the form of x^2+bx+c, x^2+bxy+cy^2, or x^2y^2+bxy+c we can use mental math to factor. We need to find two numbers whose product is c, and whose sum is b.
For t^{2}-11t+30, since the product of -6 and -5 is 30, and the sum of -6 and -5 is -11, the factorization is t^{2}-11t+30=\left(t-6\right)\!\left(t-5\right)
AC Method: In this method, we first calculate the product of a and c in ax^2+bx+c. For this problem, we have (1) \cdot (30) = 30.

The number 30 can be factored into the product of two numbers in the following ways:  egin{array}{lll}1(30)\amp -1(-30)\amp 2(15)\amp -2(-15)
ewline3(10)\amp -3(-10)\amp 5(6)\amp -5(-6)
ewline\end{array} Looking at the corresponding sums, we want a sum of -11, and this sum happens with (-5)+(-6)=-11 So we write  egin{aligned}[t]t^{2}-11t+30\amp =t^{2}-5t-6t+30
ewline \amp =t\!\left(t-5ight)-6\!\left(t-5ight)
ewline \amp =\left(t-6ight)\!\left(t-5ight)\end{aligned}Generic Rectangles Method: First, we set up generic rectangles by putting the first term and third term in t^{2}-11t+30 into the top left and bottom right rectangles:
The first term's coefficient, 1, can be factored into the product of two numbers (where the first factor is positive) in the following ways: \begin{array}{llll}1(1)\amp \end{array}

The third term, 30, can be factored into the product of two numbers in the following ways: \begin{array}{llll}1(30)\amp -1(-30)\amp 2(15)\amp -2(-15)\newline3(10)\amp -3(-10)\amp 5(6)\amp -5(-6)\newline\end{array}

We put each pair into the corresponding places next to those generic rectangles, and try to match the area of those rectangles with t^{2}-11t+30 by guess-and-check. The following generic rectangles show the solution:
Dimensions of those generic rectangles in the diagram give us the solution: \begin{aligned}[t]t^{2}-11t+30\amp =\left(t-6\right)\!\left(t-5\right)\end{aligned}
We will factor 3t^{2}+28t+9 where a=3, b=28, and c=9.
AC Method: In this method, we first calculate the product of a and c in ax^2+bx+c. For this problem, we have (3) \cdot (9) = 27.

The number 27 can be factored into the product of two numbers in the following ways:  egin{array}{lll}1(27)\amp -1(-27)\amp 3(9)\amp -3(-9)
ewline\end{array} Looking at the corresponding sums, we want a sum of 28, and this sum happens with 27+1=28 So we write  egin{aligned}[t]3t^{2}+28t+9\amp =3t^{2}+27t+t+9
ewline \amp =3t\!\left(t+9ight)+t+9
ewline \amp =\left(3t+1ight)\!\left(t+9ight)\end{aligned}Generic Rectangles Method: First, we set up generic rectangles by putting the first term and third term in 3t^{2}+28t+9 into the top left and bottom right rectangles:
The first term's coefficient, 3, can be factored into the product of two numbers (where the first factor is positive) in the following ways: \begin{array}{llll}1(3)\amp \end{array}
The third term, 9, can be factored into the product of two numbers in the following ways: \begin{array}{llll}1(9)\amp -1(-9)\amp 3(3)\amp -3(-3)\newline\end{array}

We put each pair into the corresponding places next to those generic rectangles, and try to match the area of those rectangles with 3t^{2}+28t+9 by guess-and-check. The following generic rectangles show the solution:
Dimensions of those generic rectangles in the diagram give us the solution: \begin{aligned}[t]3t^{2}+28t+9\amp =\left(3t+1\right)\!\left(t+9\right)\end{aligned}

solution.p: Lets start by noting that 2t^{2} is a common factor to each term, so we may write

To factor this expression further we make the following observations:
the leading coefficient is 1
the last term is negative which means that the factorization will have the following form
(t-\phantom{3})(t+\phantom{3})
We look for factors of -10 that add to -3; the factors that work are 2 and -5 so
Note that this answer can be checked by using the FOIL (First Outside Inside Last) technique (exercise).

p.p: We will factor 49x^{2}-81 where a=49, b=0, and c=-81.

Difference of Squares Formula: The formula for a difference of squares is a^2-b^2 = (a+b)(a-b) Note that the polynomial 49x^{2}-81 matches the formula's right side, and we have: \begin{aligned}[t]49x^{2}-81\amp =\left(7x\right)^2-\left(9\right)^2\newline \amp =\left(7x+9\right)\!\left(7x-9\right)\end{aligned}
AC Method: In this method, we first calculate the product of a and c in ax^2+bx+c. For this problem, we have (49) \cdot (-81) = -3969.

The number -3969 can be factored into the product of two numbers in the following ways:  egin{array}{lll}1(-3969)\amp -1(3969)\amp 3(-1323)\amp -3(1323)
ewline7(-567)\amp -7(567)\amp 9(-441)\amp -9(441)
ewline21(-189)\amp -21(189)\amp 27(-147)\amp -27(147)
ewline49(-81)\amp -49(81)\amp 63(-63)\amp -63(63)
ewline\end{array} Looking at the corresponding sums, we want a sum of 0, and this sum happens with (-63)+63=0 So we write  egin{aligned}[t]49x^{2}-81\amp =49x^{2}-63x+63x-81
ewline \amp =7x\!\left(7x-9ight)+9\!\left(7x-9ight)
ewline \amp =\left(7x+9ight)\!\left(7x-9ight)\end{aligned}Generic Rectangles Method: First, we set up generic rectangles by putting the first term and third term in 49x^{2}-81 into the top left and bottom right rectangles:
The first term's coefficient, 49, can be factored into the product of two numbers (where the first factor is positive) in the following ways: \begin{array}{llll}1(49)\amp 7(7)\amp \end{array}
The third term, -81, can be factored into the product of two numbers in the following ways: \begin{array}{llll}1(-81)\amp -1(81)\amp 3(-27)\amp -3(27)\newline9(-9)\amp -9(9)\amp \end{array}

We put each pair into the corresponding places next to those generic rectangles, and try to match the area of those rectangles with 49x^{2}-81 by guess-and-check. The following generic rectangles show the solution:
Dimensions of those generic rectangles in the diagram give us the solution: \begin{aligned}[t]49x^{2}-81\amp =\left(7x+9\right)\!\left(7x-9\right)\end{aligned}

solution.p: We use the properties of exponents to help us here, remembering that \left(a^m\right)^{n}=a^{mn}

p.p: We will factor 9x^{2}-6x+1 where a=9, b=-6, and c=1.

Perfect Square Formula: The formula for perfect square trinomials is (a \pm b)^2=a^2 \pm 2ab + b^2 Note that the polynomial 9x^{2}-6x+1 matches the formula's right side, and we have: \begin{aligned}[t]9x^{2}-6x+1\amp =\left(3x\right)^2-2\left(3x\right)\left(1\right)+\left(1\right)^2\newline \amp =\left(3x-1\right)\!\left(3x-1\right)\newline \amp =\left(3x-1\right)^{2}\end{aligned}
AC Method: In this method, we first calculate the product of a and c in ax^2+bx+c. For this problem, we have (9) \cdot (1) = 9.

The number 9 can be factored into the product of two numbers in the following ways:  egin{array}{lll}1(9)\amp -1(-9)\amp 3(3)\amp -3(-3)
ewline\end{array} Looking at the corresponding sums, we want a sum of -6, and this sum happens with (-3)+(-3)=-6 So we write  egin{aligned}[t]9x^{2}-6x+1\amp =9x^{2}-3x-3x+1
ewline \amp =3x\!\left(3x-1ight)-\left(3x-1ight)
ewline \amp =\left(3x-1ight)\!\left(3x-1ight)
ewline \amp =\left(3x-1ight)^{2}\end{aligned}Generic Rectangles Method: First, we set up generic rectangles by putting the first term and third term in 9x^{2}-6x+1 into the top left and bottom right rectangles:
The first term's coefficient, 9, can be factored into the product of two numbers (where the first factor is positive) in the following ways: \begin{array}{llll}1(9)\amp 3(3)\amp \end{array}
The third term, 1, can be factored into the product of two numbers in the following ways: \begin{array}{llll}1(1)\amp -1(-1)\amp \end{array}

We put each pair into the corresponding places next to those generic rectangles, and try to match the area of those rectangles with 9x^{2}-6x+1 by guess-and-check. The following generic rectangles show the solution:
Dimensions of those generic rectangles in the diagram give us the solution: \begin{aligned}[t]9x^{2}-6x+1\amp =\left(3x-1\right)\!\left(3x-1\right)\newline \amp =\left(3x-1\right)^{2}\end{aligned}

solution.p: There are a few ways to solve quadratic equations- the easiest way to solve this particular type of problem is to use the square root method.

Note that all quadratic equations have two (possibly repeated) solutions; in this problem both solutions are real. Each solution can be checked by substituting it into the original equation- this is left as an exercise.
There are a few ways to solve quadratic equations- the easiest way to solve this particular type of problem is to use the square root method.

p.m: \begin{aligned} 61x^2-23 = 0\amp \Rightarrow 61x^2=23 \\ \amp \Rightarrow x^2=\frac{23}{61} \\ \amp \Rightarrow x= -\sqrt{\frac{23}{61}}\text{ or } x=\sqrt{\frac{23}{61}}\\ \amp \Rightarrow x= -\frac{\sqrt{23}}{\sqrt{61}}\cdot\frac{\sqrt{61}}{\sqrt{61}}\text{ or } x=\frac{\sqrt{23}}{\sqrt{61}}\cdot\frac{\sqrt{61}}{\sqrt{61}}\\ \amp \Rightarrow x= -\frac{\sqrt{1403}}{61}\text{ or } x=\frac{\sqrt{1403}}{61}\\ \end{aligned}

solution.p: Note that all quadratic equations have two (possibly repeated) solutions; in this problem both solutions are real. Each solution can be checked by substituting it into the original equation- this is left as an exercise. We rationalized the denominator in each solution by multiplying by a factor of 1 using \frac{\sqrt{61}}{\sqrt{61}}.
There are a few ways to solve quadratic equations- the easiest way to solve this particular type of problem is to factor and then use the zero product principle.

Note that all quadratic equations have two (possibly repeated) solutions; in this problem both solutions are real. Each solution can be checked by substituting it into the original equation- this is left as an exercise.
There are a few ways to solve this equation- this equation does not easily factor, so we will use the Quadratic Formula:
so x=\frac{-5-\sqrt{17}}{2}\text{ or }\frac{-5+\sqrt{17}}{2}.

Note that all quadratic equations have two (possibly repeated) solutions; in this problem both solutions are real. Each solution can be checked by substituting it into the original equation- this is left as an exercise.
There are a few ways to solve quadratic equations- the easiest way to solve this particular type of problem is to use the zero product principle.
In this problem there is just one, repeated solution.
The solution can be checked by substituting it into the original equation- this is left as an exercise.

statement.p: Subtract one fraction from the other: \displaystyle{-\frac{1}{6}-\frac{7}{18}}

solution.p: To add or subtract two fractions with different denominators, we first have to find the common denominator.
In this case, the least common multiple of 6 and 18 is 18.
Look at the first fraction \displaystyle{-\frac{1}{6}}. To change the denominator to 18, we multiply 3 at both the top and bottom, and we have:
Since the second fractions denominator is the same as the common denominator, there is no need to make changes to the second fraction.
Finally, we add or subtract the numerators and keep the common denominator unchanged. The whole process is:
We must follow the order of operations when simplifying this expression. Begin by doing the division.
According to the order of operations, the multiplication has higher priority than the addition.
